Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) exhibit excellent catalytic activity in reducing 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) using sodium borohydride (NaBH₄). However, due to their high surface energy, AuNPs tend to aggregate, leading to reduced catalytic efficiency and stability. To overcome this limitation, in this study, azobenzene (Azo) modified Fe3O4 was utilized as a magnetic carrier to load β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) modified AuNPs. The reversible multivalent host-guest interaction between Azo and β-CD was employed to develop a recyclable and photo-regeneratable catalyst, Fe₃O₄@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs (IPTS refers to (3-isocyanoisopropyl) triethoxysilane). Through photo-induced isomerization of Azo between its trans and cis forms, the AuNPs could be selectively removed from or reloaded onto the carrier. This process is controlled by UV irradiation (causing trans-to-cis isomerization) or visible light irradiation (inducing cis-to-trans isomerization), thereby switching the host-guest behavior of the photo-responsive linker Azo@β-CD. The results showed that the average size of the synthesized βCD-AuNPs was 8.56 nm, and the crystal structure of the AuNPs was validated by HR-TEM and XRD. The clearance rate of 4-NP reaches 99 % in 5 min with the rate constant (k) of 0.3001 min−1 at 25 °C. AuNPs, in both 20th recycled and 12th photo-regenerated composite catalysts, exhibited high efficiency in reducing nitroaromatic pollutant 4-NP. This work presents a pathway to achieve a green and sustainable technology for efficiently intoxicating aqueous nitroaromatic pollutants. As one of principal contaminants in the aquatic environment, p-nitrophenol (4-NP) has a high water solubility, toxicity and stability, presenting persistent harm to internal organs of human body, and potentially carcinogenic at very low doses [4–8]. Currently, reduction of 4-NP to non-toxic p-aminophenol (4-AP) is a common method of intoxicating 4-NP [9–13]. However, degrading 4-NP into 4-AP without a catalyst is an inherently impractical task due to the slow rate of direct reduction. Therefore, an efficient and recoverable catalyst is highly desirable to remediate 4-NP-contaminated aquatic environments [14,15]. Gold is generally chemically inert as a precious metal at the microscale [16–18]. But at the nanoscale, especially under 10 nm, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) exhibit outstanding catalytic activity, strong chemical stability, and biocompatibility [19,20], demonstrating potential applicability in wide range of fields including catalysis [21], drug delivery [22], environmental detection [23], biological imaging [24,25], and contaminated water remediation [26]. The catalytic performance of AuNPs could be improved by appropriately controlled size and exposure to certain crystal surfaces via nanotechnology. Nevertheless, because of their high surface energy, aggregation of AuNPs significantly lowers their catalytic activity. Additionally, agglomeration into the microscale takes place if AuNPs are to be retrieved by centrifugation and filtering [ 27], rendering it difficult to achieve the efficient recoverability of AuNPs catalyst. A prevalent approach to address this problem is to attach AuNPs to the carrier's surface and disperse the composite catalyst in the solution to accelerate the reaction while ensuring AuNPs' stability and recoverability. Carriers used to immobilize AuNPs include metal oxides [28–30], polymers [31–33], graphene oxide [34–37], hydrogels [38–41], carbon nano tubes [42–44], clay [45,46], metal-organic frameworks [47–51], to achieve synergistic reinforcement performance in form of composite nanoscale inorganic particles. Nanoscale inorganic composite particles have also been widely applied as photocatalytic materials [52–56]. Magnetic nanoscale ferric oxide (Fe3O4) is one of several carriers that not only exhibits the high specific surface area and adsorption properties of typical nanometer materials, but also has high magnetic responsiveness [57] that facilitates the separation of the catalysts from the reaction system, simultaneously preventing the aggregation of AuNPs and maintaining the catalytic activity, reusability, and stability [58–60]. The combination of AuNPs and magnetic materials effectively circumvents the cumbersome and time-consuming centrifugation separation of AuNPs, which otherwise causes excessive loss of AuNPs, suitable for efficient environmental remediation [61,62]. However, it is challenging for industrial processes to separate AuNPs from the carrier for catalyst regeneration once AuNPs have been poisoned and lost their catalytic activity if the bonding is irreversible. Here in this work, we proposed a regeneratable AuNPs catalytic system based on the reversible bonding between AuNPs and nanoscale carrier Fe3O4 via switchable molecular recognition between β-CD and azobenzene (Azo) with good photo-induced cis-trans isomerism [63]. Molecular recognition occurs when the host and guest molecules have good structural complementarities and unite through non-covalent bonds (dipole interaction, metal coupling, van der Waals force, hydrogen bond, etc.) [64–67]. Azo holds trans configuration in its natural state, which can be compatible with β-CD to form host-guest complexes. If exposed to 365 nm ultraviolet light, trans-Azo transforms into cis-Azo that cannot form host-guest complexes with β-CD due to stronger polarity and steric hindrance and would fall off from β-CD. If exposed to 460 nm blue light, cis-Azo could be further reversed into trans-Azo and reestablish bonding with β-CD. Through irradiation under different UV–vis wavelengths, molecular switch of photo-induced host-guest recognition occurs [68,69]. Therefore, a recyclable and repairable AuNPs catalytic composite system was designed to contain two components. One component is the inner magnetic core part Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo, which is synthesized by SiO2 coating on carrier Fe3O4 with by alkyl silane coupling agent that builds a bridge to condensed with IPTS to incorporate Azo groups. The other component is outer shell part βCD-AuNPs that was synthesized by reacting HS-functionalized β-CD with AuNPs to form Au-S bond. The two components reversibly unit or separate following molecular recognition principle in which Azo groups in inner component with good photo-induced cis-trans isomerism exhibit responsive host-guest molecular recognition with β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) in outer component, forming a molecular switch. This mechanism enables the reversible linking of Azo-βCD, thereby establishing a recyclable and repairable catalytic system Fe3O4@IPTS- Azo@βCD-AuNPs. When the AuNPs lose their catalytic activity after repeated use, the deactivated outer component βCD-AuNPs could be removed from inner carrier Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo through ultraviolet irradiation, and as-prepared βCD-AuNPs would be reloaded onto inner carrier via blue-light irradiation to realize photo-regeneration of the composite catalyst. The reduction of nitroaromatic compounds proceeds through several stages, generating three distinct products. It is demonstrated that Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs are more effective nano-catalysts for 4-NP catalysis, with better catalytic rate constants when compared to earlier research on AuNPs catalysts. 3.4 Catalytic performance evaluation of recycled and regenerated Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs As shown in the Fig. S6 (a–d), the surface morphology, functional group composition and chemical composition of Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs were characterized before and after the 4-NP reduction, and no significant changes were observed. It indicates that the nanomaterials were able to maintain their structural and compositional integrity throughout the reaction process, demonstrating good stability. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the catalytic reduction of 4-NP using Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs was repeated over multiple cycles. The overall catalytic efficiency remained above 95 % across 10 consecutive cycles. The consistent performance suggests the durability of the multivalent host-guest interaction between Azo and β-CD. A slight decrease in catalytic efficiency was observed after 20 cycles, possibly due to mass loss and agglomeration-induced deactivation of AuNPs following repeated magnetic separation from the reaction solution. Nonetheless, the recovery experiments strongly suggest that Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs possess a stable structure and maintain good catalytic activity, even after multiple recycling tests. XPS analysis was used to monitor the surface chemical composition of Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo under various conditions to investigate the photo-responsive multivalent host-guest interaction between βCD-AuNPs and Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo. These conditions included: immersion in a βCD-AuNPs solution for 24 h (labeled as Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs), exposure to 365 nm UV light for 15 min (labeled as Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs-UV), and exposure to 460 nm blue light followed by re-immersion in βCD-AuNPs solution (labeled as Re-immersed in βCD-AuNPs). As shown in Fig. 6(b), XPS spectra of these samples revealed the presence of O, N, C, and Si elements in all cases. The differences in the Au composition among the samples indicate the occurrence of photo-induced trans-cis isomerization of Azo. Specifically, immersion in βCD-AuNPs solution resulted in the formation of the Azo@β-CD linker, as evidenced by the appearance of the Au peak in the XPS spectrum of Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs. Upon UV irradiation, this Azo@β-CD linker was dismantled, as evidenced by the disappearance of the Au peak in the spectrum of Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs-UV. Re-immersion in βCD-AuNPs after blue light exposure led to the re-establishment of the Azo@β-CD linkage, indicated by the reappearance of the Au peak. These observations confirm that the Azo@β-CD linker in the composite catalyst is photo-responsive, with UV light breaking the linkage and blue light re-establishing it. The elemental compositions shown in Table S1 (Entries 4–6) further validate the photo-responsiveness of the Azo@β-CD linker. The photo-reversible linker of Azo@β-CD enables the regeneration of composite catalyst via UV irradiation followed by visible illumination, realizing the reusability of magnetic carrier Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo and green isolation of deactivated βCD-AuNPs. Fig. 6(c) displays the 4-NP catalytic reduction efficiency of the regenerated catalyst. The regeneration processes were performed 12 consecutive times, and the catalytic reduction of 4-NP was investigated each time, showing full conversion (all above 99 %) for each regenerated catalyst. It implies highly stable structure and high efficiency of the regenerated catalyst Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs, which shows great potential in sustainably degrading aquatic nitroaromatic pollutants. 3.5 Composite catalyst design, function mechanism and substrate scope of nitroaromatic compounds Magnetic nanoparticle Fe3O4 was surface-modified by TEOS to form organo-silyl interlayer to link silane-functionalized Azo (IPTS-Azo) by silanol condensation to synthesize Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo whose trans- form interact with β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) of βCD-AuNPs by molecular recognition to generate stable composite catalyst Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs. This multifunctional structure provides the composite catalyst with magnetic separation ability and photo-induced regeneration. In catalyzing the reduction reaction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), this composite catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance and was able to recycle magnetically and regenerate in a photo-reversible manner. In the catalyst regenerating experiments, UV irradiation was used to remove the AuNPs that lost the catalytic activity after long-term use, and fresh βCD-AuNPs could be reloaded onto the magnetic carrier Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo under blue light irradiation by simple re-soaking method. This photo-induced regeneration mechanism effectively prolonged the service life of the catalysts and reduced the cost of the reaction. The composite catalyst design and functional mechanism is shown in Fig. 7 . Besides 4-NP, 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), 4-nitrotroluene, 4-nitrotrochlorobenzene were reduced with NaBH4 catalyzed by Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@ βCD-AuNPs at 25 °C. As shown in Fig. S7 (a), conversion rate of four nitroaromatic compounds are larger than 95 %, suggesting that the catalyst may be utilized to treat a variety of nitroaromatic hydrocarbons. Catalyst activity and efficiency can be determined partly by measuring the turnover frequency (TOF). Stronger catalyst activity and a quicker reaction rate correlate with higher TOF values. The TOF value of four nitroaromatic compounds is shown in Fig. S7 (b). It is found that electron-withdrawing chlorine substituent contribute to large TOF, implying that 4-nitrochlorobenzeze is readily reduced. In comparison, electron-donating groups like methyl and hydroxyl lead to relatively small TOF. Comparison of TOF value between 4-NP and 2-NP provides the reactivity difference that 4-NP is more readily reduced than 2-NP, which could be due to the steric hindrance and intramolecular H-bond of 2-NP (see SI for illustration of intramolecular H-bond). The experimental details and completion time (t c), percentage conversion, and TOF values of four nitroaromatic compounds are shown in Table S3. 4 Conclusions In summary, this study developed a recyclable and regeneratable composite catalyst, Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs, using the photo-responsive cis-trans isomerization of azobenzene molecules. This strategy combines AuNPs with magnetic carriers, utilizing Azo@β-CD as a linker to attach AuNPs onto Fe3O4 through reversible multivalent host-guest interactions. The photo-induced isomerization of Azo allows for the controlled attachment and detachment of AuNPs, akin to assembling and disassembling components of a macro-machine. The composite catalyst Fe3O4@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs demonstrated a highly stable structure and maintained excellent efficacy across 20 recycling tests. The consecutive “loading” and “unloading” of AuNPs under visible and ultraviolet light achieves a new design paradigm for sustainable industrial catalysts. Notably, the investigation into the catalytic activity of the 12th regenerated catalyst showed nearly complete conversion of 4-NP, highlighting the high reliability of AuNPs in being effectively removed from and reattached to the magnetic carrier. This work presents a recoverable and regenerative AuNPs catalytic system with high efficiency in removing aquatic nitroaromatic pollutants, providing an alternative pathway to sustainable environmental remediation. coredata.dc:description: Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) exhibit excellent catalytic activity in reducing 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) using sodium borohydride (NaBH₄). However, due to their high surface energy, AuNPs tend to aggregate, leading to reduced catalytic efficiency and stability. To overcome this limitation, in this study, azobenzene (Azo) modified Fe3O4 was utilized as a magnetic carrier to load β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) modified AuNPs. The reversible multivalent host-guest interaction between Azo and β-CD was employed to develop a recyclable and photo-regeneratable catalyst, Fe₃O₄@IPTS-Azo@βCD-AuNPs (IPTS refers to (3-isocyanoisopropyl) triethoxysilane). Through photo-induced isomerization of Azo between its trans and cis forms, the AuNPs could be selectively removed from or reloaded onto the carrier. This process is controlled by UV irradiation (causing trans-to-cis isomerization) or visible light irradiation (inducing cis-to-trans isomerization), thereby switching the host-guest behavior of the photo-responsive linker Azo@β-CD. The results showed that the average size of the synthesized βCD-AuNPs was 8.56 nm, and the crystal structure of the AuNPs was validated by HR-TEM and XRD. The clearance rate of 4-NP reaches 99 % in 5 min with the rate constant (k) of 0.3001 min−1 at 25 °C. AuNPs, in both 20th recycled and 12th photo-regenerated composite catalysts, exhibited high efficiency in reducing nitroaromatic pollutant 4-NP. This work presents a pathway to achieve a green and sustainable technology for efficiently intoxicating aqueous nitroaromatic pollutants.
